resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:71130018</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:DLC</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Foss, Lukas, 1922-2009.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Lukas Foss papers, circa 1926-2000 (bulk 1936-1995).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection documents the life and career of Lukas Foss. The music materials consist of holograph manuscript scores and parts, and sketches. Later compositions, especially those which reflect his interests in twelve-tone and aleatory music, are accompanied by extensive supplementary notes, tone rows, mathematical charts, and performance instructions. Photocopied scores and parts often include annotations by Foss or various conductors and performers. The correspondence contains items to and from such notable musical figures as Luciano Berio, Leonard Bernstein, Pierre Boulez, John Cage, Elliott Carter, Aaron Copland, Henry Cowell, Paul Hindemith, Mauricio Kagel, Yehudi Menuhin, Olivier Messiaen, Eugene Ormandy, Kristoff Penderecki, Mistislav Rostropovich, Karlheinz Stockhausen, Igor Stravinsky, Toru Takemitsu, and Iannis Xenakis. The business papers include correspondence with organizations and lesser known individuals, programs, clippings, and legal or financial documents related to Foss' tenure with various orchestras in the United States and abroad, including the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, Tokyo Philharmonic, Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra. In addition, there is information on many of Foss' commissions, performances, and teaching relationships involving the Buffalo, Chicago, Cincinnati and Cleveland orchestras and the American Symphony, as well as other orchestras, festivals, universities and conservatories across the country. Additional files consist of lecture notes and correspondence with universities, ideas for concert programming, writings by or about Foss, and miscellaneous documents for other topics of interest. The collection also contains Foss' extensive file of correspondence, clippings, notes, programs, and promotional items related to specific musical works. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The business papers include correspondence with organizations and lesser known individuals, programs, clippings, and legal or financial documents related to Foss' tenure with various orchestras in the United States and abroad, including the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, Tokyo Philharmonic, Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra. <objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Ambassador Auditorium Collection</unittitle>
                  <unitid>ARS.0043</unitid>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Stanford, California 94305-3076</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>636</extent>
                     <extent>containers of various sizes with multiple types of print materials, photographic materials, audio and video materials, realia, posters and original art work (682.05 linear feet).</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <unitdate>1974-1995</unitdate>
                  <abstract>The Ambassador Auditorium Collection contains the files of the various organizational departments of the Ambassador Auditorium as well as audio and video recordings. The materials cover the entire time period of April 1974 through May 1995 when the Ambassador Auditorium was fully operational as an internationally recognized concert venue. The materials in this collection cover all aspects of concert production and presentation, including documentation of the concert artists and repertoire as well as many business documents, advertising, promotion and marketing files, correspondence, inter-office memos and negotiations with booking agents. The materials are widely varied and include concert program booklets, audio and video recordings, concert season planning materials, artist publicity materials, individual event files, posters, photographs, scrapbooks and original artwork used for publicity. Many of the print materials include handwritten comments from office personnel and administrators, and many of the artist photographs are autographed. Since the various office personnel maintained their own files, and the same information was often needed in more than one office at a time, the collection contains duplicate copies of many items. Although efforts were made to eliminate duplicate material from the same file or the same series, duplicate copies of items exist among the files from different offices. In an effort to maintain the original content of these files, the cross-file duplicate items were retained in the collection.</abstract>
                  <physloc>Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries Stanford, California 94305-3076</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English</language>, <language>French</language>, <language>German</language>, <language>Italian</language>, <language>Korean</language>, <language>Spanish</language>, <language>Russian</language>, <language>Hungarian</language>, <language>Dutch</language>, <language>Latin</language>, <language>Malay</language>, <language>Thai</language>, <language>Czech</language>, <language>Slovak</language>.</langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>Correspondence, clippings, publications, and certificates relating to Dr. Jarzynski's career, and, in part, to that of his wife. The correspondence, 1917-42, includes letters from Ohio Attorney General John W. Bricker regarding draft board examinations during World War I, and an acknowledgment of condolences from Ignace Jan Paderewski. In addition, the collection contains the minutes, 1916-22, of the Medical and Dental Arts Club, handwritten in Polish, mimeographed minutes, 1934-39, of the annual meetings of the Musical Arts Association, and miscellaneous materials relating to the League of Polish Organizations. </abstract>
                  <name>

                     <role>

               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Ross Lee Finney collection : sound and video recordings</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1938-1986</unitdate>
                  <unitid>*L (Special) 98-16</unitid>
                  <unitid>20475</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Finney, Ross Lee, 1906-1997</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>The New York Public Library. Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound.</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center</addressline>
                        <addressline>40 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-7498</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <physdesc>137 sound recordings.</physdesc>
                  <abstract>Ross Lee Finney (1906-1997) was an American composer and teacher. Born in Wells, MN, he studied at the University of Minnesota with Donald Ferguson, in Paris with Nadia Boulanger,and at Harvard with Edward Burlingame Hill. He also studied with Roger Sessions (1935), Alban Berg (1931-1932), and Gian Francesco Malipiero (1937). Finney taught at Smith College (1929-49) ; Mt. Holyoke College (1938-40) ; Hartt School of Music (1941-42), and Amherst College (1946-1947). He was a visiting lecturer at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor (1948-1949), and later became a professor there (1949-73). During his time at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Finney served as chairman of the composition department, and established an electronic music laboratory.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

He was a visiting lecturer at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor (1948-1949), and later became a professor there (1949-73). During his time at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Finney served as chairman of the composition department, and established an electronic music laboratory.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Jan Peerce collection of sound recordings</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1932-1983</unitdate>
                  <unitid>*L (Special) 95-03</unitid>
                  <unitid>20483</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Peerce, Jan, 1904-1984</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>The New York Public Library. Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound.</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center</addressline>
                        <addressline>40 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-7498</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <physdesc>ca. 700 sound recordings; 7 unpublished video recordings</physdesc>
                  <abstract>The collection contains non-commercial recordings of live and recorded performances and interviews of Jan Peerce spanning the years 1938-1983. The collection also features performers such as: singers Zinka Milanov, Roberta Peters, Leonard Warren, Cesare Siepi, Robert Merrill, Lawrence Tibbett, Virginia Raye and Viola Philo ; conductors Arturo Toscanini, Fausto Cleva, Harry Horlick and David Rubinoff ; and interviewers Ed Sullivan, Johnny Carson and Mike Douglas. Radio and television (audio only) programs included are: The A & P Gypsies, Radio City Music Hall On the Air, Carnegie Hall, The Chevrolet Hour, The Ed Sullivan Show, The Mike Douglas Show, and The Tonight Show. Works featured are selections from operas such as "La boheme," "I pagliacci," "Don Giovanni," "Cavalleria Rusticana," "La traviata," "Lucia di Lammermoor" and "Rigoletto" ; musicals such as "Fiddler on the Roof" ; and songs by Handel and Schubert, among others.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Artur Rodzinski collection, 1868-1989 (bulk 1932-1957).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Artur Rodzinski Collection focuses on Rodzinski's professional work as a conductor and his personal life in the United States, Europe and Latin America. The collection covers Rodzinski's performances (live, radio and sound recordings), schedules, and biographical information. The materials primarily consist of correspondence, annotated music, magazine articles, newspaper clippings, legal documents, programs and advertisements. Other items include: photographs, notes, an address book, announcements, bills, brochures, catalogs and schedules. A portion of the collection comes from Rodzinski's wife, Halina, including items relating to her book, personal correspondence and articles published after the conductor's death. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>

<objectXMLWrap>

                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:50277839</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Grand Rapids (Mich.) concert and theater programs scrapbook, 1900,1931.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Scrapbook, 1900,1931, includes Grand Rapids (Mich.) musical performances of the Furniture City Band, Grand Rapids Symphony Orchestra, and various organ recitals at local churches, and bands, orchestras, singers, and dancers from other states and nations. Famous names found in the programs include: Ann Pavlova, Martha Graham, Alma Gluck, John Philip Sousa and his band, and others. The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, and the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra are also represented in the scrapbook. Most of the performances were in Grand Rapids, although some were held in New York (City). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Sandra L. Hughes Theatre Collection, 1975-[ongoing]. 1975-</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes administrative materials, articles of incorporation of her company (Great American Mime Experiment), programs, notes, reviews, correspondence, costume designs for her production "Once upon an orchestra" (1976), together with the Cleveland Orchestra, directed and choreographed by Sandra Hughes who was also the principal performer; production materials (programs, awards, notes) for "Mime dreaming", created for television by Sandra Hughes (WVIZ PBS television, Cleveland, Ohio, 1976); production materials for "The keeper", a mime drama, conceived and directed by Sandra Hughes, performed at Lake Erie College, 1978 and Antioch College, Yellow Springs, Ohio, 1979; photographs, touring brochure, program, correspondence, reviews for the production "The image makers", directed, choreographed and also performed by Sandra Hughes at Alliance Theatre, Atlanta, Georgia, 1984 as well as materials related to the production of Lysistrata by Aristophanes, directed by Sandra Hughes, 1986, and a touring brochure of Gateway Performance Productions (2000-2002). </abstract>

resource.title: Jacob Druckman collection of noncommercial sound recordings [sound recording]
resource.abstract: This collection contains noncommercial recordings from Druckman's private collection. These recordings include live performances of Druckman's works as well as works of other composers. Some of the artists featured are Leonard Bernstein, Pierre Boulez, Phyllis Curtin, Jan DeGaetani, Lorin Maazel, Zubin Mehta, Leonard Slatkin and many others. Orchestras include the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Cleveland Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the Boston Orchestra.
resource.displayEntry: Jacob Druckman collection of noncommercial sound recordings [sound recording]

                  <abstract>The Artur Rodzinski Collection focuses on Rodzinski’s professional work as a conductor and his personal life in the United States, Europe and Latin America.  It covers Rodzinski’s performances (live, radio and sound recordings), schedules and biographical information.  The collection also includes material related to Rodzinski’s wife Halina.  The materials primarily consist of correspondence, annotated music, magazine articles, newspaper clippings, legal documents, programs and advertisements.  Most of the collection is in English, with a significant amount of material in Polish.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: The Artur Rodzinski Collection focuses on Rodzinski’s professional work as a conductor and his personal life in the United States, Europe and Latin America.  It covers Rodzinski’s performances (live, radio and sound recordings), schedules and biographical information.  The collection also includes material related to Rodzinski’s wife Halina.  The materials primarily consist of correspondence, annotated music, magazine articles, newspaper clippings, legal documents, programs and advertisements.  Most of the collection is in English, with a significant amount of material in Polish.
